thread.title: Wall Street set to close lower as jobs data sparks mixed reaction
thread.title_full: Wall Street set to close lower as jobs data sparks mixed reaction | MENAFN.COM

author: ProactiveInvestors  N.America
title: Wall Street set to close lower as jobs data sparks mixed reaction
text:
(MENAFN - ProactiveInvestors)Global indices were again a sea of red and Wall Street shares opened sharply lower as the US non-farm number triggered mixed reactions.
It showed 173000 new jobs were created in America last month. This was fewer (weaker) than expected but the figure is likely to be revised upwards in coming weeks and the sentiment appeared to generally be that it was a positive report.
That didn't seem to appeal to investors. At 3:37 p.m. in New York the Dow Jones lost 245 points lower at 16129 while the tech heavy Nasdaq lost 42 points to head to 4691.
The S&P500 index dropped 26 points lower at 1924 while across the Pond in London Footsie trailed 124 points lower.
On Friday's key jobs report economists had been expecting 217000 new positions to have been created so it fell short of that but significantly the unemployment rate fell to its lowest level in seven years to 5.1% from 5.3% -a  bigger drop than the Street had expected.
Some say it all comes together to suggest a rate rise will happen while others policy makers have suggested markets and a weakening Chinese growth outlook muddy the argument for a hike as soon as this month.
In contrast in Canada 12000 jobs were added in August but the unemployment rate tacked up to 7% as a significant numbers are looking for work. Before last month the  unemployment rate had been fairly steady since January at 6.8%.
Over the last 12 months Canada's economy has added 193000 jobs Statistics Canada said in a release Friday.
"The steady unemployment rate hides a more complicated picture in the Canadian economy. With GDP shrinking slightly across the year today’s figures could be seen as a small win for Bank of Canada governor Stephen Poloz" said Dennis de Jong managing director at UFX.com
Turning to stocks Kilobits Parma (NASDAQ:KBIO) was the biggest gainer on Nasdaq adding over 49%. Clothing brand GAP was down 1.73% at US32.46 as its August sales stats disappointed.
Amazon.com ( NASDAQ:AMZN ) dropped 1% as the online retail giant said its cloud-computing unit Amazon Web Services (AWS) agreed to acquire video-encoding company Elemental Technologies for an undisclosed amount. Shares lost 0.6% to US501.68.
Netflix ( NASDAQ:NFLX ) fell further shedding 2.4%  even as Cantor Fitzgerald reiterated its ‘buy’ rating on the video-streaming company.
Blackberry ( Blackberry (NASDAQ:BBRY TSE:BB) declined 1.5% reversing an earlier gain. The Canadian smartphone maker agreed to buy its rival mobile security software maker Good Technology for 425mln in cash.
